titlestmt.titleproper: Princeton University Library Collection of Western Americana Photographs, 1840-1998: Finding Aid WC064

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-07-16 09:49:27 -0400.
profiledesc.descrules: Finding aid content adheres to that prescribed by Describing Archives: A Content Standard.

did.unittitle: Princeton University Library Collection of Western Americana Photographs
did.abstract: An open collection of more than 5,000 Western Americana photographs, consisting mostly of documentary photographs of the Trans-Mississippi West from the late 1860s to early 1900s. Subjects include American Indians (especially studio portraits), natural wonders, cities, towns, buildings, and economic activities (mining, railroads, logging, and agriculture). Some photographs relate to the indigenous populations of Mexico and Central America. The dimensions, physical formats, and photographic processes of the photographs vary widely. Many of the photographs in this collection are available in the Princeton University Digital Library.
did.physloc: Boxes H4 and H5 (Lummis glass plate negatives) and H6 (California Gold Rush daguerreotype) are stored in special vault facilities.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Started in the 1970s, this is an open collection of more than 5,000 photographs consisting mostly of documentary photographs of the Trans-Mississippi West from the late 1860s to early 1900s. Subjects include American Indians (especially studio portraits), natural wonders, cities, towns, buildings, and economic activities (mining, railroads, logging, and agriculture). Some photographs relate to the indigenous populations of Mexico and Central America. The dimensions, physical formats, and photographic processes of the photographs vary widely.

Photographers represented include Charles Milton Bell, John Nicholas Choate, John K. Hillers, Charles Fletcher Lummis, Eadweard Muybridge, Frank A. Rinehart, Bernard Gurney Randall, Carlton E. Watkins, Orloff R. Westmann, Ben Wittick, and many others; as well as photographers whose work was marketed commercially by the Keystone View Company, Underwood & Underwood, and other firms. The collection also includes the work of some contemporary photographers, such as Ulli Steltzer and Kenji Kawano.

For earlier accessions, photographs that are identified with the letter "S" are small prints, many of which are stereographic photographs; those identified with the letters "M" and "L" are mostly albumen prints, and the latter are oversize; photographs with the letter "H" include tintypes, ambrotypes, daguerreotypes, and lantern slides; and photographs marked with "X" include mammoth prints as well as gelatin silver prints.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Photographs aquired prior to 2015 are arranged by size and format. Photographs aquired since 2015 are arranged in the order in which they were accessioned.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open to researchers.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Single photocopies may be made for research purposes. No further photoduplication of copies of material in the collection can be made when Princeton University Library does not own the original. Inquiries regarding publishing material from the collection should be directed to RBSC Public Services staff at rbsc@princeton.edu. The library has no information on the status of literary rights in the collection and researchers are responsible for determining any questions of copyright.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: This is an open collection that continually grows from gifts and purchases.

appraisal.head: Appraisal
appraisal.p: No material was separated during processing.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Many of the items in this collection are available in digital format at the Princeton University Digital Library: http://pudl.princeton.edu/collections/pudl0017

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of specific item; Date (if known); Princeton University Library Collection of Western Americana photographs, Box and Folder Number; Special Collections, Princeton University Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was processed and described by Heather Shannon in 2006. Finding aid created by Faith Charlton in 2014. Finding aid updated periodically with new accessions by Faith Charlton, Kelly Bolding, and Chloe Pfendler.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Consists of three mounted albumen photographs and a photographic copy of a painting depiciting Cree and Chippewa (Ojibwa) life near Fort Assinniboine, Montana Territory, around the 1880s. These photographs, taken by the Fort Assiniboine-based team Arnold & Barnard, show the distribution of rations at the fort; ten men in formal or war dress facing the camera; and a family sitting in front of tepees. The photographic copy reproduces a painting of an indigenous family on a horse moving camp. The albumen photographs have Arnold & Barnard's imprint on the verso, and the reproduction of the painting has the imprint of photographer W. H. Culver of Maiden, Montana Territory, with Barnard's signature on the verso.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Augur Down Books in 2020.
